title: Switch from embedded RocksDB to separate SurrealDB server process
description:
Currently using embedded RocksDB which only allows one process to access the database at a time. This prevents running both the web server and MCP server simultaneously.

**Benefits of switching to separate SurrealDB process:**
- Both web and MCP servers can run simultaneously
- No HTTP overhead (both still use loaa-core directly)
- Still local-first (SurrealDB runs on localhost)
- Better for development (can inspect DB with CLI while servers run)
- Simpler than refactoring MCP to call HTTP APIs

**Implementation steps:**
1. Add surrealdb package to devenv.nix
2. Update connection.rs to use Ws instead of RocksDb
3. Add startup scripts/docs for running SurrealDB locally
4. Update both server startup instructions
5. Test concurrent access with both servers running

title: Build MCP server with rmcp for Claude Code integration
description:
Implement MCP server using the official rmcp Rust SDK to expose Loa'a functionality to Claude Code (or other MCP clients). This enables natural language task management.

**Tools to expose:**
- create_kid(name) - Add a new kid to the system
- list_kids() - Show all kids with their current balances
- create_task(name, description, value, cadence) - Create a new task
- list_tasks() - Show all available tasks
- update_task(id, ...) - Modify an existing task
- delete_task(id) - Remove a task
- complete_task(task_id, kid_id) - Mark task complete for a kid (creates ledger entry, resets if recurring)
- get_ledger(kid_id) - Show kid's transaction history and balance
- adjust_balance(kid_id, amount, description) - Manual balance adjustment

**Technical:**
- Use rmcp crate (official MCP SDK)
- Integrate with existing loaa-core repositories and workflows
- Run as stdio server (Claude Code connects via stdin/stdout)
- Add to loaa-mcp crate

**Testing:**
- Configure in Claude Code MCP settings
- Test all tools via natural language commands
- Verify data persistence

title: Design core data models (Task, Kid, Ledger)
description:
## Overview

Design and implement the core data models that represent the domain concepts of Loa'a. These models form the foundation for all business logic and will be used across web, MCP, and future components.

## Goals

- Define Rust structs for all Phase 1 entities
- Implement serialization/deserialization
- Add validation logic
- Create helper methods for common operations
- Document the data model design

## Core Entities for Phase 1

### Kid

Represents a child in the household.

```rust
struct Kid {
    id: Uuid,
    name: String,
    created_at: DateTime<Utc>,
    updated_at: DateTime<Utc>,
}
```

**Validation:**
- Name must be non-empty
- Name should be unique (helper to check)

### Task

Represents a chore or activity that can be completed for money.

```rust
struct Task {
    id: Uuid,
    name: String,
    description: String,
    value: Decimal,           // Monetary value in dollars
    cadence: Cadence,         // How often it resets
    last_reset: DateTime<Utc>,
    created_at: DateTime<Utc>,
    updated_at: DateTime<Utc>,
}

enum Cadence {
    Daily,
    Weekly,
    OneTime,
}
```

**Validation:**
- Name must be non-empty
- Value must be positive
- Description can be empty

**Helper Methods:**
- `needs_reset() -> bool` - Check if task should reset based on cadence
- `reset()` - Update last_reset timestamp

### LedgerEntry

Represents a transaction in a kid's ledger.

```rust
struct LedgerEntry {
    id: Uuid,
    kid_id: Uuid,
    amount: Decimal,
    entry_type: EntryType,
    description: String,
    created_at: DateTime<Utc>,
}

enum EntryType {
    Earned,     // Money earned from task completion
    Adjusted,   // Manual correction by parent
}
```

**Validation:**
- kid_id must reference existing Kid
- amount can be positive (earned) or negative (correction)
- description can be empty

**Helper Methods:**
- None needed yet

### Ledger (Aggregate)

Not stored directly, but calculated from LedgerEntry records.

```rust
struct Ledger {
    kid_id: Uuid,
    balance: Decimal,
    entries: Vec<LedgerEntry>,
}

impl Ledger {
    fn calculate_balance(entries: &[LedgerEntry]) -> Decimal {
        entries.iter()
            .map(|e| e.amount)
            .sum()
    }
}
```

## Tasks

### 1. Create Models Module

In `crates/core/src/models/`:
- `mod.rs` - Re-exports all models
- `kid.rs` - Kid struct and impl
- `task.rs` - Task, Cadence structs and impl
- `ledger.rs` - LedgerEntry, EntryType, Ledger structs and impl
- `common.rs` - Shared types (if needed)

### 2. Add Dependencies

Update `crates/core/Cargo.toml`:
- `uuid` for IDs
- `chrono` for timestamps
- `rust_decimal` for monetary values (avoid floating point\!)
- `serde` for serialization

### 3. Implement Serde Traits

All structs need:
- `#[derive(Serialize, Deserialize)]`
- Proper handling of Decimal serialization
- DateTime serialization (ISO 8601)

### 4. Add Validation

Create validation methods:
- `Kid::validate(&self) -> Result<()>`
- `Task::validate(&self) -> Result<()>`
- `LedgerEntry::validate(&self) -> Result<()>`

### 5. Write Tests

Test files in `crates/core/src/models/`:
- Test struct creation
- Test validation logic
- Test helper methods
- Test serialization round-trip

### 6. Document Design

Add `docs/data-models.md` with:
- ER diagram (text-based)
- Relationships between entities
- Future extensions (Phase 2+ models)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] All Phase 1 models defined in `loaa-core`
- [ ] Structs derive Debug, Clone, Serialize, Deserialize
- [ ] Validation methods exist and have tests
- [ ] Helper methods work correctly
- [ ] Documentation explains model design
- [ ] No database-specific code (stays generic)

## Design Decisions

**Why Decimal for money:**
- Floating point causes rounding errors
- Decimal gives exact precision
- Industry standard for financial calculations

**Why UUIDs:**
- Globally unique, no coordination needed
- Easy to generate client-side
- Better than auto-increment for distributed systems (future-proof)

**Why separate EntryType enum:**
- Clear intent (earned vs adjustment)
- Extensible (can add Redeemed in Phase 5)
- Makes queries easier (filter by type)

**Why not a Balance table:**
- Balance is derived, not stored
- Source of truth is transaction history
- Avoids sync issues

**Why last_reset on Task:**
- Simple approach for MVP
- Can track when task was last available
- Alternative: separate TaskInstance table (too complex for MVP)

## Future Extensions (Not Now)

These will be added in later phases:

**Phase 2:**
- `User` - Authentication
- `TaskCompletion` - Approval workflow
- `Session` - Login sessions

**Phase 3:**
- `TaskPrerequisite` - Task dependencies

**Phase 4:**
- `BountyRule` - Dynamic value increases

**Phase 5:**
- `Reward` - Redeemable rewards
- `Redemption` - Reward redemption records
- Add `EntryType::Redeemed`

## References

- rust_decimal docs: https://docs.rs/rust_decimal/
- chrono docs: https://docs.rs/chrono/
- Domain-driven design principles

## Dependencies

Should be done after:
- Basic project structure exists (already done)

Can be done in parallel with:
- loaa-ycs (Leptos setup)
- loaa-p1z (SurrealDB setup)

## Success Metrics

When done:
- Models compile without warnings
- Tests pass
- Models feel natural to work with
- Clear path to implement business logic
- Easy to extend in future phases

title: Integrate SurrealDB in embedded mode
description:
## Overview

Integrate SurrealDB in embedded mode as the primary database for Loa'a. This provides a local, zero-config database without requiring a separate server process.

## Goals

- Get SurrealDB embedded mode working
- Create basic database connection
- Verify CRUD operations work
- Establish database abstraction in `loaa-core`
- Set up database file storage location

## Tasks

### 1. Add SurrealDB Dependencies

Update `crates/core/Cargo.toml` with:
- `surrealdb` with embedded features
- Choose storage backend (RocksDB or SpeedeDB)
- Add async runtime support

### 2. Create Database Module

In `crates/core/src/db/`:
- `mod.rs` - Database connection and initialization
- `connection.rs` - SurrealDB client wrapper
- Error types and Result aliases

### 3. Initialize Embedded Database

- Configure database path (`.data/db/` in project root)
- Set up namespace and database
- Create connection pool if needed
- Handle startup and shutdown

### 4. Test Basic Operations

Write tests that prove:
- Can connect to embedded DB
- Can create/read/update/delete records
- Can query with SurrealQL
- Database file persists between restarts

### 5. Update devenv/gitignore

- Add database files to `.gitignore`
- Document database location in README
- Add any needed system dependencies to `devenv.nix`

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] SurrealDB embedded mode initializes on startup
- [ ] Can create records and query them
- [ ] Database file exists on disk
- [ ] Data persists after restart
- [ ] Tests pass for basic CRUD operations
- [ ] No separate database server required

## Technical Decisions

**Storage Backend:**
- **RocksDB** (default) - Battle-tested, good performance
- **SpeedeDB** - Newer, potentially faster
- **Decision**: Start with RocksDB (more mature)

**Database Location:**
- `loaa/.data/db/` - Keeps data separate from code
- Gitignored
- Can be backed up separately

**Connection Strategy:**
- Singleton connection for now (single-user)
- Connection pool might be needed later for multi-user

**Schema Mode:**
- Start schemaless for rapid iteration
- Add schema validation in later phases

## Example Code Structure

```rust
// In loaa-core/src/db/mod.rs
pub struct Database {
    client: Surreal<Db>,
}

impl Database {
    pub async fn init(path: &str) -> Result<Self> {
        let db = Surreal::new::<RocksDb>(path).await?;
        db.use_ns("loaa").use_db("main").await?;
        Ok(Self { client: db })
    }
    
    pub async fn create<T>(&self, table: &str, data: T) -> Result<T> {
        // CRUD operations
    }
}
```

## References

- SurrealDB embedded docs: https://surrealdb.com/docs/surrealdb/integration/sdks/rust
- RocksDB backend: https://docs.rs/surrealdb/latest/surrealdb/engine/local/struct.RocksDb.html
- SurrealQL reference: https://surrealdb.com/docs/surrealql

## Dependencies

None - foundational work

## Blockers

**Potential Issues:**
- SurrealDB compilation time (Rust dependencies can be slow)
- Platform-specific build requirements
- Limited documentation for embedded mode

**Mitigation:**
- If compilation is too slow, consider SQLite instead
- Check platform requirements early
- Consult SurrealDB Discord for help

## Experimentation Notes

We're choosing SurrealDB partly to experiment with it. If we encounter issues:
- Migration path to SQLite is straightforward
- Keep database abstraction in `loaa-core` to make swap easier
- Document learnings for future projects

## Success Metrics

When done:
- DB initializes in <1 second
- CRUD operations work
- Clear error messages
- Database abstraction is clean and testable
- Confident we can build on this foundation

Set up Leptos web application with SSR
description:
## Overview

Set up the Leptos web framework with server-side rendering (SSR) to serve as the foundation for the Loa'a web application.

## Goals

- Get Leptos working with SSR and hydration
- Serve a basic "Hello World" page
- Set up Axum as the server
- Configure hot reload for development
- Verify the full-stack Rust setup works

## Tasks

### 1. Add Leptos Dependencies

Update `crates/web/Cargo.toml` with:
- `leptos` with SSR feature
- `leptos_axum` for server integration
- `axum` for HTTP server
- `tokio` for async runtime
- `tower` and `tower-http` for middleware

### 2. Create Basic Leptos App

In `crates/web/src/`:
- `app.rs` - Main Leptos component
- `main.rs` - Axum server setup
- Basic routing
- SSR configuration

### 3. Configure Development Workflow

- Set up `leptos` CLI config or cargo-leptos
- Configure hot reload
- Add npm/pnpm if needed for CSS/JS bundling
- Update `justfile` with dev server command

### 4. Create Hello World Page

Simple page that proves:
- Server renders initial HTML
- Client hydrates and becomes interactive
- Routing works
- Can pass data server → client

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `cargo run -p loaa-web` starts web server
- [ ] Browser shows a page (not 404 or error)
- [ ] Page hydrates (console shows no hydration errors)
- [ ] Can navigate between routes
- [ ] Hot reload works (changes appear without full restart)

## Technical Notes

**Leptos SSR Modes:**
- We want SSR with hydration (not CSR-only or SSR-only)
- This gives fast initial load + interactive UI

**Server Framework:**
- Use Axum (modern, async, integrates well with Leptos)
- Leptos provides `leptos_axum` integration crate

**Styling:**
- Start with basic CSS
- Consider Tailwind or styled components later

## References

- Leptos Book: https://book.leptos.dev/
- Leptos examples: https://github.com/leptos-rs/leptos/tree/main/examples
- Leptos Axum integration docs

## Dependencies

None - this is foundational work

## Blockers

None known. If Leptos setup is too complex, we can pivot to Axum + HTMX (see roadmap.md).

## Success Metrics

When done, we should have:
- Working dev server with hot reload
- Basic page that renders and hydrates
- Clear path to add more components
- Confidence that Leptos is the right choice

title: Implement voice-first UI with Claude API integration
description:
Add microphone button to web UI that enables hands-free voice commands for managing tasks and completions. This eliminates the need for Claude Code as a separate app.

**Features:**
- Microphone button in web UI (tap to speak)
- Speech-to-text conversion (Web Speech API or cloud service)
- Backend integration with Claude API
- MCP client protocol implementation in Rust
- Voice confirmation shown in UI
- Error handling for unclear speech

**Architecture:**
User speaks → Web UI captures audio → Speech-to-text → Backend → Claude API (with MCP tool definitions) → MCP Client Protocol Handler → Local MCP Server → Execute → UI confirmation

**Technical Requirements:**
- Implement MCP client protocol in Rust (relay tool calls between Claude API and local MCP server)
- Use @anthropic-ai/sdk or equivalent Rust HTTP client for Claude API
- Handle streaming responses and tool calling
- Audio capture and speech-to-text (browser or server-side)

**Phase 6 - Deferred because:**
- Phase 1 MCP server works with Claude Code today
- Requires building MCP client protocol (what Claude Code does for free)
- Want to validate workflow first

**Dependencies:**
- Requires loaa-gz0 (MCP server) to be complete
